Federated Learning Over Wireless Channels: Dynamic Resource Allocation and Task Scheduling

Shunfeng Chu, Jun Li, Jianxin Wang, Zhe Wang, Ming Ding, Yijin Zang, Yuwen Qian, and Wen Chen S. Chu, J. Li, J. Wang, Y. Zhang and Y. Qian are with the School of Electronic and Optical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, China (e-mail: shunfeng.chu@njust.edu.cn; jun.li@njust.edu.cn; wangjxin@njust.edu.cn; yijin.zhang@njust.edu.cn; admon@njust.edu.cn).Z. Wang is with the School of Computer Science and Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, China (e-mail: zwang@njust.edu.cn).M. Ding is with Data61, CSIRO, Sydney, Australia (e-mail: ming.ding@data61.csiro.au).W. Chen is with the Department of Electronic Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China (e-mail: wenchen@sjtu.edu.cn
Abstract

With the development of federated learning (FL), mobile devices (MDs) are able to train their local models with private data and sends them to a central server for aggregation, thereby preventing sensitive raw data leakage. In this paper, we aim to improve the training performance of FL systems in the context of wireless channels and stochastic energy arrivals of MDs. To this purpose, we dynamically optimize MDs' transmission power and training task scheduling. We first model this dynamic programming problem as a constrained Markov decision process (CMDP). Due to high dimensions rooted from our CMDP problem, we propose online stochastic learning methods to simplify the CMDP and design online algorithms to obtain an efficient policy for all MDs. Since there are long-term constraints in our CMDP, we utilize Lagrange multipliers approach to tackle this issue. Furthermore, we prove the convergence of the proposed online stochastic learning algorithm. Numerical results indicate that the proposed algorithms can achieve better performance than the benchmark algorithms.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, Markov decision processes, stochastic learning, resource allocation, dynamic programming

I Introduction

In the last decade, we have witnessed a series of amazing breakthroughs, such as AlphaGo, machine learning and artificial intelligence (AI), which have become the most cutting-edge technology in both academia and industry communities [1]. Distributed machine learning based on mobile edge computing (MEC) of the wireless networks is also one of the current hot research directions [2]. The sample data for machine learning can be obtained by collecting massive amounts of data from mobile devices (MD) distributed in the wireless network. By training these data, the training performance of machine learning can be greatly improved.

Although offloading the local sample data of distributed MDs for centralized learning significantly improves the performance of machine learning, this mechanism suffers from two flaws. First, transmission delays from distributed MDs to the central cloudy via backbone network are extremely large. Second, the local data often contains the private information of MDs, and uploading the private information to the central cloudy will lead to the risk of personal privacy leakage. To cope with these two issues, federated learning (FL) has been introduced to act as an emerging distributed machine learning paradigm, which is indeed a way to combine MEC with traditional machine learning. In this manner, MDs train their local data and send their local model updates to a task publisher iteratively instead of uploading the raw data to a central server [3, 4], which, in general, brings the following two benefits. (I) The communication latency and the energy consumption for computation can be significantly reduced owing to the fact that MDs are not required to upload huge amounts of local data for training to an edge server. (II) MDs upload their local model instead of the raw data to the edge server, which greatly reduces the risk of personal privacy information leakage [5].

Despite the aforementioned advantages of FL, there are still many challenges that have not been solved until now. Some existing studies [6, 7] adopted an idealized assumption that all MDs participating in FL are immune to the wireless and computation resource constraints. [8] only focused on a practical Federated-Averaging algorithm for distributed DNN training and the training performance. Many studies [9, 10, 11, 12] have been committed to further reducing the communication overhead by developing compression methods. However in practice, MDs usually suffer from energy consumption constraints that may reduce the network lifetime and training efficiency.

In addition, frequent wireless communications is usually required for uploading and downloading the model parameters, which would increase the bandwidth cost and the training latency [13]. Therefore, it is necessary to design a feasible resource scheduling scheme to optimize the resource scheduling problem in the FL process. Without taking into account the energy constraints and battery dynamics of MDs, [14] formulated a FL over a wireless networks as a static optimization problem, and exploited the problem structure to decompose it into three static convex sub-problems. The work [15] proposed a static scheduling scheme to efficiently execute distributed learning tasks in an asynchronous manner while minimizing the gradient staleness on wireless edge nodes with heterogeneous computing and communication capacities. However, many properties of MEC networks are usually time-varying in the FL process and thus the methods in [16] will result in considerable performance loss. The work [16, 17] model the channel and energy dynamically, and exploit the dynamic scheduling algorithm to obtain the asymptotically optimal resluts. Thus, it is of vital importance to develop efficient dynamic resource scheduling schemes to improve the performance of FL.

In this paper, we utilize constrained Markov decision processes (CMDP) as a mathematical tool to obtain an optimal algorithm for dynamic resource scheduling for FL, where each MD send local model updates trained on their local raw data iteratively to a common edge server, and the edge server aggregates the parameters from MDs participating in local training and broadcasts the aggregated parameters to all the MDs. In particular, each MD possesses computing units with computing capability, which can be used for local machine learning with local raw data. In order to improve the training performance of FL111In general FL, existing work [18] used the accuracy of the test set to measure the performance of machine learning after training. Since the quantitative analysis of the accuracy in the test set is relatively difficult, we use the size of local dataset accumulated from MDs over iterations to evaluate the accuracy of the machine learning model [13]., we propose an efficient stochastic optimization algorithm for scheduling resources of MDs in the FL processes by obtaining an efficient setting of the size of raw data for local training, and the transmission power of MDs to upload the local model.

Our main contributions are listed as follows.

  1. 1.

    Due to the dynamic nature of wireless network and battery status of MDs, we consider resource scheduling of FL in dynamic scenarios. Thus, we model the resource scheduling problem of the FL process as a CMDP problem, and improve the performance of FL by optimizing the size of the local training data at the MD side.

  2. 2.

    Since the state-action space dimension in the constrained MDP problem is large and there are a few constraints in the dynamic problem, we simplify the stochastic optimization problem by proving an equivalent Bellman equation and using the Lagrange multiplier method.

  3. 3.

    We use approximate MDP and stochastic learning methods to analyze the constrained MDP problem, and design centralized online algorithms to obtain resource scheduling policy for all MDs.

  4. 4.

    We also provide effective analysis for the convergence of the online stochastic learning algorithms.

Although the idea of applying CMDP to design dynamic resource scheduling is not new, we are motivated to address the resource scheduling issues of resource constraints and dynamics of FL. To achieve high-quality learning performance, a reasonable constrained dynamic scene is essential to the resource scheduling issues [19, 20]. Previous work has utilized CMDP as a mathematical model to design effective algorithms for resource scheduling in wireless networks [13, 21, 22], which is considered as an effective tool for solving dynamic problems and time-related state problems. Inspired by this, we apply CMDP as the mathematical scene to address the resource scheduling problem in the FL process. Nevertheless, previous work still has some shortcomings in solving CMDP problems. The literature [13] adopted a deep learning algorithm that allows the edge server to learn and find optimal decisions without any a priori knowledge of network dynamics in the CMDP. However, reinforcement learning is poorly scalable and requires a lot of computing power and duration for training. The literature [21] obtained the optimal solution for the formulated CMDP offloading problem by linear programming and Q-learning method. Neither method is suitable for large-scale networks, which will lead to the curse of dimension. The work [22] developed a threshold-based algorithm to obtain the optimal delay-power tradeoff efficiently, in which the authors used the special structure of the mathematical model to solve the CMDP problem, and this method does not possess the universality of solving the problem.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II describes the system model and dynamic analysis. CMDP-based dynamic resource scheduling problem is formulated in Section III. Section IV proposes approximate Markov decision process and stochastic learning methods to simplify the CMDP problem, and designs online algorithms to obtain an efficient policy. Section V presents the simulation results. Finally, Section VI concludes this paper.

II System Model

Consider a wireless FL system consisting of an edge server and N𝑁N MDs as shown in Fig. 1. Each MD is equipped with computing and energy harvesting modules. Having access to a vast range of local data, each MD is able to train the machine learning model locally using the harvested energy from the environment. To improve the model training efficiency and protect data privacy, the FL technique is adopted as an iterative model updating process between the edge server and MDs.

We first briefly introduce the main procedures as follows. In each learning iteration t𝑡t, the n𝑛n-th MD first selects bn​(t)subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n}(t) bits of training data from the local data set, where the size of selected data is determined by the edge server according to the energy status of the MD, i.e., the battery energy at the beginning of this iteration. Here, we assume that the edge server knows the energy status of all MDs in advance at the beginning of the learning iteration. Then, each MD performs local training and obtains the local model parameters. Afterwards, the edge server decides whether or not to upload the local parameters for MDs for aggregation according to MDs' remaining energy and channel state. If the n𝑛n-th MD participates, it transmits the parameters to the edge server in the uplink using the power of Pn​(t)subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡P_{n}(t). Finally, the edge server aggregates the local training parameters from all the participating MDs and then it broadcasts the updated global training parameters (e.g., weighted average over the local parameters) back to all the MDs. At the end of this iteration, each MD opportunistically harvests energy from the environment and stores the energy in the rechargeable battery. The above process is repeated until the learning model reaches the desired accuracy level.

In the following subsections, we will explain the above process in more details. We mainly discuss each learning iteration in three stages: dynamic energy harvesting, local model training, model parameter transmission and aggregation.

II-A Dynamic Energy Harvesting

We assume that the n𝑛n-th MD is equipped with a rechargeable battery with a limited capacity of Enmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛maxE_{n}^{\text{max}}.222For the ease of analysis, we quantize the battery capacity in to Enmax+1superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max1E_{n}^{\text{max}}+1 uniform levels {0,1,⋯,Enmax}01⋯superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max\{0,1,\cdots,E_{n}^{\text{max}}\} [23]. At the beginning of each iteration t𝑡t, we denote the n𝑛n-th MD's energy state as Ensta​(t)superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛sta𝑡E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t) which is the remaining energy carried from the previous iteration. According its energy state, the edge server decides whether or not to proceed to local model training and uplink parameter transmission for each MD. We let Encop​(t)superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛cop𝑡E_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t) denote the n𝑛n-th MD's computation energy for local model training and Encom​(t)superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛com𝑡E_{n}^{\text{com}}(t) denote the communication energy for uplink parameter transmission, respectively, which will be discussed in more details in the next two subsections. Note that each MD's energy consumption cannot exceed the energy state in this iteration. At the end of the iteration t𝑡t, we consider that each MD is able to harvest energy from the environment and store the energy in the rechargeable battery. We denote the energy harvesting process for the n𝑛n-th MD by {𝑬narr​(⋅):n∈𝒩}conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝑬𝑛arr⋅𝑛𝒩\{\bm{E}_{n}^{\text{arr}}(\cdot):n\in\mathcal{N}\}, which follows an independent stationary Poisson distribution with average arrival rate 𝔼​[Enarr]=λn𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛arrsubscript𝜆𝑛\mathbb{E}[E_{n}^{\text{arr}}]=\lambda_{n} [24].

Similar to [25], the energy state of the n𝑛n-th MD at the beginning of iteration t+1𝑡1t+1 can be updated by the following recursion,

Ensta(t+1)=min{[Ensta(t)−⌈Encom(t)+Encop(t)⌉]++Enarr(t),Enmax},t≥1,\begin{split}E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)=\min\Big{\{}[E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t)&-\left\lceil E_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)+E_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t)\right\rceil]^{+}\\ &+E_{n}^{\text{arr}}(t),E_{n}^{\text{max}}\Big{\}},\quad t\geq 1,\end{split} (1)

where ⌈⋅⌉⋅\lceil\cdot\rceil denotes the ceiling operator, and x+≜max⁡{x,0}≜superscript𝑥𝑥0x^{+}\triangleq\max\{x,0\}.

II-B Local Model Training

At the beginning of each learning iteration t𝑡t, each MD first selects bn​(t)subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n}(t) bits of data samples from the local dataset to perform a machine learning algorithm, and then it obtains the local model parameters. Intuitively, the choice of bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n} depends on the available energy in the battery. The MD can train a larger size of the training data if it has more sufficient battery energy in this iteration. Otherwise, it trains less data or takes no training for this iteration. We assume it consumes Cnsubscript𝐶𝑛C_{n} CPU cycles to train a unit sampled data on the n𝑛n-th MD. The CPU frequency, denoted by fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} (in CPU cycle/s), is considered as a measurement of computation capacity of the n𝑛n-th MD. In iteration t𝑡t, the processing time of local training on the n𝑛n-th MD is given by

τncop​(t)=bn​(t)​Cnfn,superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛cop𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛\tau_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t)=\frac{{b_{n}(t){C_{n}}}}{{f_{n}}}, (2)

According to [14], the computation energy Encop​(t)superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛cop𝑡E_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t) consumed by local training of the n𝑛n-th MD in the iteration t is given by

Encop​(t)=α​bn​(t)​Cn​fn2,superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛cop𝑡𝛼subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝐶𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛2E_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t)=\alpha b_{n}(t){C_{n}}{f_{n}^{2}}, (3)

where α𝛼\alpha is the effective capacitance of the computing chipset for each MD.

II-C Model Parameter Transmission and Aggregation

After performing the local training, the MDs then upload their updated local model parameters back to the edge server. Let ϵn​(t)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑡\epsilon_{n}(t) denote the upload decision of the n𝑛n-th MD at the iteration t𝑡t, where ϵn​(t)=1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑡1\epsilon_{n}(t)=1 means the n𝑛n-th MD is assigned to a subchannel and is willing to upload parameters to the edge server through the assigned channel, and ϵn​(t)=0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑡0\epsilon_{n}(t)=0 indicates that it is not assigned to a subchannel or keeps silent. Intuitively, an MD is more likely to upload if it has sufficient remaining energy while in a good channel state. For the uplink transmission, we adopt OFDMA technique, where the channels are orthogonal cross the different links. We assume that there are L𝐿L orthogonal subchannels in the FL system and each MD can only occupy at most one subchannel. Let hn​(t)subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡h_{n}(t) denote the uplink channel gain between the n𝑛n-th MD and the edge server in the iteration t, where the channel gains of all sub-channels between the server and a single MD are same.

We model the channel gain hn​(t)subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡h_{n}(t) as a discrete-state block fading, where the channel gain between the n𝑛n-th MD and edge server stay is discrete random variable with a general distribution Pr⁡[h¯n]Prsubscript¯ℎ𝑛\Pr[\bar{h}_{n}] [26, 27, 28, 29, 30]. We further assume that hn​(t)subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡h_{n}(t) stays invariant within each iteration and are independently and identically distributed (i.i.d.) across different iterations and MDs.

If the n𝑛n-th MD is allowed to upload (ϵn​(t)=1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑡1\epsilon_{n}(t)=1), it will transmit the local model parameter to the edge server with power Pn​(t)subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡P_{n}(t) (Pn​(t)>0subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡0P_{n}(t)>0) in the uplink. Otherwise, the n𝑛n-th MD keeps silent (Pn​(t)=0subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡0P_{n}(t)=0). We assume that the size of the local training parameters of all MDs is the same, which is denoted by M𝑀M.333We assume all MDs have the same structures of the local network model and bit precision (typically floating point precision) of the local network parameters, respectively. The uplink transmission rate for the n𝑛n-th MD is given by

Rn​(t)=ϵn​(t)​W​log2⁡(1+Pn​(t)​hn​(t)σ2),subscript𝑅𝑛𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑡𝑊subscript21subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡superscript𝜎2R_{n}(t)=\epsilon_{n}(t)W{\log_{2}}\left({1+\frac{{{P_{n}(t)}h_{n}(t)}}{{{\sigma^{2}}}}}\right), (4)

where W𝑊W is the bandwidth of subchannel between each MD and the server, and σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is the power of the additive white Gaussian noise. Moreover, the corresponding uplink transmission time is expressed as

τncom​(t)=ϵn​(t)​MRn​(t).superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛com𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑡𝑀subscript𝑅𝑛𝑡\tau_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)=\frac{{\epsilon_{n}(t)M}}{{R_{n}(t)}}. (5)

The energy consumption of parameter uploading for the n𝑛n-th MD can be expressed as

Encom​(t)=Pn​(t)​τncom​(t)=ϵn​(t)​Pn​(t)​MRn​(t).superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛com𝑡subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛com𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡𝑀subscript𝑅𝑛𝑡E_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)={P_{n}(t)}\tau_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)=\frac{{{\epsilon_{n}(t)P_{n}(t)}M}}{{R_{n}(t)}}. (6)

Upon receiving the updated local parameters from the MDs, the edge server aggregates them into a global parameter and then broadcasts it to all MDs through a downlink broadcast channel. Assume that the bandwidth of the broadcast channel is sufficiently wide and the transmit power of the edge server is much higher than that of the MDs. Therefore, we ignore the downlink transmission time without much loss of generality.

III Constrained Markov Decision Process

In this section, we design and analyze the joint scheduling problem of computing and communication resources in the FL network. In the FL system, sequential decisions on local training and parameter transmission needs to be made for each iteration. From (1), we know that the remaining energy at the MD sides are correlated among adjacent iterations. We therefore formulate the joint computing and communication resource scheduling problem as a CMDP to maximize the long term system reward under energy and delay constraints.

III-A The composition of CMDP

At the beginning of each iteration, each MD uploads its current local channel state and battery energy state to the edge server. Therefore, the edge server obtains global status information to take appropriate actions for all MDs. Once the decisions are made, the edge server will download the policy to each MD. Due to the extremely small size of data for state information and action decisions, we can ignore the transmission delay and transmission energy for upload of local states and transmission of the policy in the FL network. The CMDP formulation consists of the following components:

  • •

    State: We define the global state 𝑺​(t)𝑺𝑡\bm{S}(t) of the all MDs in the t𝑡t-th iteration as 𝑺​(t)=[𝒉​(t),𝑬sta​(t)]𝑺𝑡𝒉𝑡superscript𝑬sta𝑡\bm{S}(t)=[\bm{h}(t),\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t)], which is composed of the current global channel state 𝒉​(t)=[h1​(t),…,hN​(t)]𝒉𝑡subscriptℎ1𝑡…subscriptℎ𝑁𝑡\bm{h}(t)=[h_{1}(t),...,h_{N}(t)] and the current global remaining battery energy state 𝑬sta​(t)=[E1sta​(t),…,ENsta​(t)]superscript𝑬sta𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸1sta𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑁sta𝑡\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t)=[E_{1}^{\text{sta}}(t),...,E_{N}^{\text{sta}}(t)].

  • •

    Action: Let us denote the global action 𝑨​(t)𝑨𝑡\bm{A}(t) of all MDs in the t𝑡t-th iteration by 𝑨​(t)=[𝒃​(t),ϵ​(t),𝑷​(t)]𝑨𝑡𝒃𝑡bold-italic-ϵ𝑡𝑷𝑡\bm{A}(t)=[\bm{b}(t),\bm{\epsilon}(t),\bm{P}(t)], which consists of the number of bits of training data 𝒃​(t)=[b1​(t),…,bN​(t)]𝒃𝑡subscript𝑏1𝑡…subscript𝑏𝑁𝑡\bm{b}(t)=[b_{1}(t),...,b_{N}(t)], the upload decision ϵ​(t)=[ϵ1​(t),…,ϵN​(t)]bold-italic-ϵ𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵ1𝑡…subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑁𝑡\bm{\epsilon}(t)=[{\epsilon}_{1}(t),...,{\epsilon}_{N}(t)] and the transmission power 𝑷​(t)=[P1​(t),…,PN​(t)]𝑷𝑡subscript𝑃1𝑡…subscript𝑃𝑁𝑡\bm{P}(t)=[P_{1}(t),...,P_{N}(t)].

  • •

    Transition probability: According to the dynamic energy queue given in (1), the global remaining energy 𝑬sta​(t)superscript𝑬sta𝑡\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t) under action 𝑨​(t)𝑨𝑡\bm{A}(t) is a controlled Markov chain with the transition probability of

    Pr​[𝑬sta​(t+1)|𝑬sta​(t),𝑨​(t)]=∏nPr[Enarr(t)=Ensta(t+1)−[Ensta(t)−⌈Encom(t)+Encop(t)⌉]+].Prdelimited-[]conditionalsuperscript𝑬sta𝑡1superscript𝑬sta𝑡𝑨𝑡subscriptproduct𝑛Prdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐸arr𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛sta𝑡1superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛sta𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛com𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛cop𝑡\begin{split}&\text{Pr}[\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)|\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t),\bm{A}(t)]\\ &=\prod_{n}\text{Pr}\Big{[}E^{\text{arr}}_{n}(t)=E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)\\ &\qquad\qquad\left.-\left[E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t)-\left\lceil E_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)+E_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t)\right\rceil\right]^{+}\right].\end{split} (7)

    Since the energy queue dynamic is affected by both the data training energy and communication energy, it is controlled by the actions 𝑨​(t)=(𝒃​(t),ϵ​(t),𝑷​(t))𝑨𝑡𝒃𝑡bold-italic-ϵ𝑡𝑷𝑡\bm{A}(t)=\left(\bm{b}(t),\bm{\epsilon}(t),\bm{P}(t)\right). Moreover, the global state transition probability is also Markovian, which is given by

    Pr[𝑺(t+1)|𝑺(t),𝑨(t))]=Pr[𝒉(t+1)|𝑺(t),𝑨(t))]×Pr[𝑬sta(t+1)|𝑺(t),𝑨(t))]=Pr[𝒉(t+1)]Pr[𝑬sta(t+1)|𝑺(t),𝑨(t))],\begin{split}&\text{Pr}[\bm{S}(t+1)|\bm{S}(t),\bm{A}(t))]\\ &=\text{Pr}\left[\bm{h}(t+1)|\bm{S}(t),\bm{A}(t))\right]\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\quad\times\text{Pr}\left[\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)|\bm{S}(t),\bm{A}(t))\right]\\ &=\text{Pr}\left[\bm{h}(t+1)\right]\text{Pr}\left[\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)|\bm{S}(t),\bm{A}(t))\right],\end{split} (8)

    where the second equation is due to the i.i.d. property of wireless channel.

  • •

    Reward: The model accuracy of the FL is difficult to quantify, and does not promise a closed-form. In most circumstances, one observes that the accuracy of FL training increases with the total size of local training data at each MD [13, 31]. Hence, we define the reward of the n-th MD by the product of its local training data size and its upload decision, i.e., ∑n=1Nbn​(t)​ϵn​(t)superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑡\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n}(t)\epsilon_{n}(t). If the MD is unable to upload the training parameters (ϵn​(t)=0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑡0\epsilon_{n}(t)=0), then its reward in the current iteration is 0.

We assume that each training iteration is synchronized across the MDs with the duration of τ𝜏\tau. Thus, the total time for data training and transmission should not exceed the duration of one iteration, i.e.,

τncom​(t)+τncop​(t)≤τ.superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛com𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛cop𝑡𝜏\begin{split}\tau_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)+\tau_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t)\leq\tau.\end{split} (9)

Moreover, the energy used for local training and uploading should not exceed the remaining energy Ensta​(t)superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛sta𝑡E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t) at the beginning of the t𝑡t-th iteration, which is described by the energy causality constraint of

⌈Encom​(t)+Encop​(t)⌉≤Ensta​(t).superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛com𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛cop𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝐸sta𝑛𝑡\begin{split}\left\lceil E_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)+E_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t)\right\rceil\leq E^{\text{sta}}_{n}(t).\end{split} (10)

From (9) and (10), we see that there is a tradeoff between the computing and communication phases due to limited time and battery energy in each training iteration. According to (3), if the number of training data bits bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n} increases, the computing energy consumption will increase, which leaves less energy for the communication phase. In the meanwhile, according to (2), by increasing the training bits number bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n}, the local training time will increase, which leaves less time for communication. Due to the above tradeoff, each MD needs to allocate time and energy wisely between the computing and communication phases. For example, the probability that the total remaining energy Ensta​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐸sta𝑛𝑡E^{\text{sta}}_{n}(t) at the n𝑛n-th MD equals zero can not exceed the energy outage probability constraint PrnoutsuperscriptsubscriptPr𝑛out\text{Pr}_{n}^{\text{out}}, i.e.,

Pr​[Ensta​(t)=0]≤Prnout,Prdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛sta𝑡0superscriptsubscriptPr𝑛out\begin{split}\text{Pr}[E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t)=0]\leq\text{Pr}_{n}^{\text{out}},\end{split} (11)

Here, Ensta​(t)=0superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛sta𝑡0E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t)=0 does not mean that the MD is completely powered off. We adopt a dedicated battery to support the energy harvesting circuit and the information signaling in each training iteration. The dedicated battery stores the energy that arrives at random in each iteration, and provides energy for information feedback, local training and parameter updates during the FL process. We thus assume that the MDs can exhaust its battery before the next recharge cycle [32]. Furthermore, we assume the subchannels occupied by all MDs in the current iteration cannot exceed the number of channels L𝐿L in the system, i.e.,

∑n=1Nϵn​(t)≤L.superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑡𝐿\begin{split}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\epsilon_{n}(t)\leq L.\end{split} (12)

Due to the randomness of states in each iteration and the correlation of states across the iterations, the edge server needs to make sequential decisions on bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n}, ϵnsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛\epsilon_{n} and Pnsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n} along the time horizon. Without much loss of generality, we formulate the problem as an infinite horizon CMDP, resulting in the stationary policies which do not change with time. The definition of stationary control policy is given as follows.

Definition 1:

(Stationary Control Policy) A stationary control policy is a mapping 𝐒→𝐀→𝐒𝐀\bm{S}\rightarrow\bm{A} from the state space to the action space 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}, which is given by 𝛀​(𝐒)=𝐀∈𝓐𝛀𝐒𝐀𝓐\bm{\Omega}(\bm{S})=\bm{A}\in\bm{\mathcal{A}}, ∀𝐒∈𝓢for-all𝐒𝓢\forall\bm{S}\in\bm{\mathcal{S}}.

Hence, we denote the control policy of the all MD by 𝛀​(S)=(𝒃,ϵ,𝑷)𝛀𝑆𝒃bold-italic-ϵ𝑷\bm{\Omega}(S)=\left(\bm{b},\bm{\epsilon},\bm{P}\right). Let 𝛀𝛀\bm{\Omega} be the stationary feasible control policy which should satisfy constraints (9), (10), (11) and (12).

III-B Constrained Markov Decision Process Problem

The formulation of CMDP is given in Problem 1. The aim is to find the efficient control policy that optimized the total long-term average utility of all MDs under the energy outage constraints, transmit power constraints, delay constraints, energy causality constraints and channel constraints.

Problem 1:

(CMDP Problem)

s.t. Pr​[Ensta​(t)=0]≤Prnout,Prdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛sta𝑡0superscriptsubscriptPr𝑛out\displaystyle\text{Pr}[E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t)=0]\leq\text{Pr}_{n}^{\text{out}}, (13a)
0≤Pn​(t)≤Pnmax,0subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛max\displaystyle 0\leq P_{n}(t)\leq P_{n}^{\text{max}}, (13b)

where the expectation 𝔼𝛀​[⋅]superscript𝔼𝛀delimited-[]⋅\mathbb{E}^{\bm{\Omega}}[\cdot] is taken with respect to the steady-state distribution induced by the control policy 𝛀𝛀\bm{\Omega}, and Pnmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛maxP_{n}^{\text{max}} is the maximum allowable transmit power of the n𝑛n-th MD. limT→∞1T​∑t=1T𝔼𝛀​[𝟏​[Ensta​(t)=0]]≤Prnout.subscript→𝑇1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript𝔼𝛀delimited-[]1delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐸sta𝑛𝑡0superscriptsubscriptPr𝑛out\lim_{T\rightarrow\infty}\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathbb{E}^{\bm{\Omega}}\left[\bm{1}[E^{\text{sta}}_{n}(t)=0]\right]\leq\text{Pr}_{n}^{\text{out}}. (14)

𝟏​[⋅]1delimited-[]⋅\bm{1}[\cdot] is an indicator function that takes on a value of 1 when the battery energy is exhausted at the n𝑛n-th MD. The objective function (13) in Problem 1 is the long-term average total utility of all MDs under the control policy 𝛀𝛀\bm{\Omega}. In the following analysis, we decompose Problem 1 into two stages. In stage one, we first omit the short term constraints in Problem 1 and simplify the problem as follows,

Problem 2:

(Simplified CMDP Problem)

where

Problem 3:

(Lagrange Dual Problem)

L∗superscript𝐿\displaystyle L^{*} =min𝜸⁡max𝛀⁡L​(𝛀,𝜸)absentsubscript𝜸subscript𝛀𝐿𝛀𝜸\displaystyle=\min_{\bm{\gamma}}\max_{\bm{\Omega}}L(\bm{\Omega},\bm{\gamma}) (19)
s.t.𝜸⪰0,succeeds-or-equalss.t.𝜸0\displaystyle\text{s.t.}\quad\bm{\gamma}\succeq 0,

According to [33], there exists an optimal control policy 𝛀∗superscript𝛀\bm{\Omega}^{*} and a series of non-negative Lagrangian multipliers 𝜸∗superscript𝜸\bm{\gamma}^{*} such that 𝛀∗superscript𝛀\bm{\Omega}^{*} maximizes the Lagrange function L​(𝛀∗,𝜸∗)𝐿superscript𝛀superscript𝜸L(\bm{\Omega}^{*},\bm{\gamma}^{*}), and the inequality condition holds:

L​(𝛀,𝜸∗)≤L​(𝛀∗,𝜸∗)≤L​(𝛀∗,𝜸),∀𝛀,∀𝜸⪰0.\begin{split}L(\bm{\Omega},\bm{\gamma}^{*})\leq L(\bm{\Omega}^{*},\bm{\gamma}^{*})\leq L(\bm{\Omega}^{*},\bm{\gamma}),\\ \forall\bm{\Omega},\quad\forall\bm{\gamma}\succeq 0.\end{split} (20)

𝛀∗superscript𝛀\bm{\Omega}^{*} and 𝜸∗superscript𝜸\bm{\gamma}^{*} are the original optimal solution and the dual optimal solution, respectively. Problem 2 can be regarded as an infinite-dimensional linear programming problem with the feasible region 𝓓​(t)𝓓𝑡\bm{\mathcal{D}}(t), which is a special type of convex problem. Thus, the duality gap between the original optimal and the dual optimal are 00. The original optimal solution is obtained by solving the dual problem.

Generally, Bellman equation is a necessary condition for a dynamic programming to be optimized. Given Lagrange multipliers 𝜸𝜸\bm{\gamma}, the classical infinite-horizon average-utility CMDP problem Problem 2 can be solved by the Bellman equation [28]. Thus, we can obtain the following equation,

G(𝜸)+V(𝑺(t))=max𝛀{g(𝑺(t),𝛀,𝜸)+∑𝑺​(t+1)Pr(𝑺(t+1)|𝑺(t),𝛀)V(𝑺(t+1))}∀𝑺​(t),t>0,\begin{split}&G(\bm{\gamma})+V(\bm{S}(t))=\max_{\bm{\Omega}}\Bigg{\{}g\left(\bm{S}(t),\bm{\Omega},\bm{\gamma}\right)+\\ &\sum_{\bm{S}(t+1)}\text{Pr}\left(\bm{S}(t+1)|\bm{S}(t),\bm{\Omega}\right)V(\bm{S}(t+1))\Bigg{\}}\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\forall\bm{S}(t),\quad t>0,\end{split} (21)

where V​(𝑺​(t))𝑉𝑺𝑡V(\bm{S}(t)) is the value function representing the average utility obtained by the control policy 𝛀𝛀\bm{\Omega} from each global state [𝒉​(t),𝑬sta​(t)]𝒉𝑡superscript𝑬sta𝑡[\bm{h}(t),\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t)]. According to (8), we know that the channel states possess independent statistical characteristics, which is not affected by the control policy. We can further simplify the Bellman equation by taking the expectation of (21) on the global channel state 𝒉​(t)𝒉𝑡\bm{h}(t).

Lemma 1:

(Equivalent Bellman Equation) Given a series of Lagrange multipliers 𝛄𝛄\bm{\gamma}, the objective function (16) can be solved by the equivalent Bellman equation as follows:

G(𝜸)+V(𝑬sta(t))=max𝛀​(𝑬sta){g¯(𝑬sta(t),𝛀(𝑬sta))+∑𝑬sta​(t+1)Pr(𝑬sta(t+1)|𝑬sta(t),𝛀(𝑬sta))V(𝑬sta(t+1))}∀𝑬sta​(t),t>0,\begin{split}&G(\bm{\gamma})+V(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t))=\max_{\bm{\Omega}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}})}\Bigg{\{}\overline{g}\left(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t),\bm{\Omega}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}})\right)+\\ &\sum_{\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)}\text{Pr}\left(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)|\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t),\bm{\Omega}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}})\right)V(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1))\Bigg{\}}\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\forall\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t),\quad t>0,\end{split} (22)

where the expectation of the value function V​(𝐡​(t),𝐄sta​(t))𝑉𝐡𝑡superscript𝐄sta𝑡V(\bm{h}(t),\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t)) is

V​(𝑬sta​(t))=𝔼𝒉​(t)​[V​(𝒉​(t),𝑬sta​(t))].𝑉superscript𝑬sta𝑡subscript𝔼𝒉𝑡delimited-[]𝑉𝒉𝑡superscript𝑬sta𝑡\begin{split}V(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t))&=\mathbb{E}_{\bm{h}(t)}[V(\bm{h}(t),\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t))].\end{split} (23)

Similarly, by taking the expectation over the channel state, we have

g¯(𝑬sta​(t),𝛀​(𝑬sta))=𝔼𝒉​(t)​[g​(𝒉​(t),𝑬sta​(t),𝛀,𝜸)],¯𝑔superscript𝑬sta𝑡𝛀superscript𝑬stasubscript𝔼𝒉𝑡delimited-[]𝑔𝒉𝑡superscript𝑬sta𝑡𝛀𝜸\begin{split}\overline{g}&\left(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t),\bm{\Omega}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}})\right)\\ \qquad&=\mathbb{E}_{\bm{h}(t)}\left[g(\bm{h}(t),\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t),\bm{\Omega},\bm{\gamma})\right],\end{split} (24)

and,

Pr​(𝑬sta​(t+1)|𝑬sta​(t),𝛀​(𝑬sta))Prconditionalsuperscript𝑬sta𝑡1superscript𝑬sta𝑡𝛀superscript𝑬sta\displaystyle\text{Pr}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)|\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t),\bm{\Omega}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}})) (25)
=𝔼𝒉​(t)[Pr(𝑬sta(t+1)|𝒉(t),𝑬sta(t),𝛀(𝑬sta)].\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{\bm{h}(t)}\left[\text{Pr}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)|\bm{h}(t),\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t),\bm{\Omega}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}})\right].

Moreover, 𝛀​(𝐄sta)={𝛀​(𝐡​(t),𝐄sta​(t))|∀𝐡​(t)}𝛀superscript𝐄staconditional-set𝛀𝐡𝑡superscript𝐄sta𝑡for-all𝐡𝑡\bm{\Omega}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}})=\{\bm{\Omega}(\bm{h}(t),\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t))|\forall\bm{h}(t)\} is a policy set under a given global energy state 𝐄sta​(t)superscript𝐄sta𝑡\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t) for all possible channel states.

From the equivalent Bellman equation (22), we notice that the equation is composed by a series of linear equations, where the dimensions of these equations depend on the number of value functions V​(𝑬sta​(t))𝑉superscript𝑬sta𝑡V(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t)). Hence, for any global energy state 𝑬sta​(t)superscript𝑬sta𝑡\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t) and the global channel state 𝒉​(t)𝒉𝑡\bm{h}(t), the optimal control policy 𝛀∗superscript𝛀\bm{\Omega}^{*} in (16) can be obtained by maximizing the right-hand side of the equation (22).

IV Approximate Markov Decision Process And Stochastic Learning

In this section, we use approximate MDP and stochastic learning methods to analyze and simplify the resource scheduling problem, and design online algorithms to obtain the resource scheduling policy for the FL system.

IV-A Approximate Markov Decision Process

According to (22), the global energy state value function V​(𝑬sta​(t))𝑉superscript𝑬sta𝑡V(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t)) is unknown, which holds a great difficulty for solving the control policy in the FL system. Due to the existence of the huge state-action space, we are unable to get the value function with the conventional value iteration method. However, we can obtain the value function and develop a solution of the Problem 1 by the value approximation and online stochastic learning. Assumed that we have obtained the value function V​(𝑬sta​(t))𝑉superscript𝑬sta𝑡V(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t)) through value approximation and online stochastic learning. Thus, the MDP problem can be solved as follow.

Problem 4:

(Optimal Partitioned Actions) For a given value function V​(𝐄sta​(t))𝑉superscript𝐄sta𝑡V(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t)), find the optimal partitioned actions 𝛀∗​(𝐄sta​(t))superscript𝛀superscript𝐄sta𝑡\bm{\Omega}^{*}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t)), which is satisfied to the Equivalent Bellman's equation in (22). The optimal control policy can be rewritten as

𝛀∗​(𝑬sta​(t))=argmax𝛀​(𝑬sta​(t))𝔼𝒉​(t){g(𝑺(t),𝛀(𝑬sta(t)),𝜸)+∑𝑬sta​(t+1)Pr(𝑬sta(t+1)|𝒉(t),𝑬sta(t),𝛀(𝑬sta(t)))V(𝑬sta(t+1))},s.t.0≤Pn​(t)≤Pnmax,ϵn​(t)∈{0,1},(9),(10)​and​(12),∀n.\begin{split}\bm{\Omega}^{*}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t))&=\arg\max_{\bm{\Omega}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t))}\mathbb{E}_{\bm{h}(t)}\left\{g(\bm{S}(t),\bm{\Omega}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t)),\bm{\gamma})\right.\\ &+\sum_{\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)}\Pr\left(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)|\bm{h}(t),\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t),\right.\\ &\left.\qquad\qquad\left.\bm{\Omega}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t))\right)V(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1))\right\},\\ \textrm{s.t.}\qquad&0\leq P_{n}(t)\leq P_{n}^{\text{max}},\\ &\epsilon_{n}(t)\in\{0,1\},\\ \qquad\quad&(\ref{delay constrains}),\ (\ref{energy constrains})\ \text{and}\ (\ref{subchannel allocation constraint}),\quad\forall n.\end{split} (26)

Given the global state value function V​(𝑬sta​(t))𝑉superscript𝑬sta𝑡V(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t)) and the realization of the global channel state 𝒉𝒉\bm{h}, the Problem 4 then becomes a static optimization problem.

IV-B Stochastic Learning

By the feature-based method, the energy state value function V​(𝑬sta)𝑉superscript𝑬staV(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}) can be approximated by a linear form of the state value function of the n𝑛n-th MD Vn​(Ensta)subscript𝑉𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛staV_{n}(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}). The global energy state value function V​(𝑬sta)𝑉superscript𝑬staV(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}) and a series of Lagrange multipliers 𝜸𝜸\bm{\gamma} will be updated according to the current energy state and channel state information. Then the proposed linear approximation architecture for the global energy state value function V​(Ensta)𝑉superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛staV(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}) is obtained by

V​(𝑬sta)=V​(E1sta,…​Ensta,…​ENsta)≈∑n=1N∑l∈𝑸nVn​(l)​𝑰​[Ensta=l]=𝑾T​𝑭​(𝑬sta),𝑉superscript𝑬sta𝑉superscriptsubscript𝐸1sta…superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛sta…superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑁stasuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑙subscript𝑸𝑛subscript𝑉𝑛𝑙𝑰delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛sta𝑙superscript𝑾𝑇𝑭superscript𝑬sta\begin{split}V(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}})&=V(E_{1}^{\text{sta}},...E_{n}^{\text{sta}},...E_{N}^{\text{sta}})\\ &\approx\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sum_{l\in\bm{Q}_{n}}V_{n}(l)\bm{I}[E_{n}^{\text{sta}}=l]=\bm{W}^{T}\bm{F}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}),\end{split} (27)

where 𝑸nsubscript𝑸𝑛\bm{Q}_{n} means energy state set of the n𝑛n-th MD, that is 𝑸n={0,1,2,…,Enmax}subscript𝑸𝑛012…superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max\bm{Q}_{n}=\{0,1,2,...,E_{n}^{\text{max}}\}. The parameter vector 𝑾𝑾\bm{W} and the feature 𝑭​(𝑬sta)𝑭superscript𝑬sta\bm{F}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}) can be elaborated as,

𝑾=[V1​(0),…​V1​(E1max),…​VN​(0),…​VN​(ENmax)]T,𝑾superscriptsubscript𝑉10…subscript𝑉1superscriptsubscript𝐸1max…subscript𝑉𝑁0…subscript𝑉𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑁max𝑇\bm{W}=\left[V_{1}(0),...V_{1}(E_{1}^{\text{max}}),...V_{N}(0),...V_{N}(E_{N}^{\text{max}})\right]^{T}, (28)

and

𝑭(𝑬sta)=[𝑰[E1sta=0],…𝑰[E1sta=E1max],…𝑰[ENsta=0],…𝑰[ENsta=ENmax]]T.𝑭superscript𝑬stasuperscript𝑰delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐸1sta0…𝑰delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐸1stasuperscriptsubscript𝐸1max…𝑰delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑁sta0…𝑰delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑁stasuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑁max𝑇\begin{split}\bm{F}(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}})=\left[\bm{I}[E_{1}^{\text{sta}}=0],...\bm{I}[E_{1}^{\text{sta}}=E_{1}^{\text{max}}],\right.\\ \left....\bm{I}[E_{N}^{\text{sta}}=0],...\bm{I}[E_{N}^{\text{sta}}=E_{N}^{\text{max}}]\right]^{T}.\end{split} (29)

Thus, we can calculate the global energy state value function by the linear form of all MDs. According to the local energy state Enstasuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛staE_{n}^{\text{sta}}, the value function of global energy state 𝑬sta={E1sta,…,ENsta}superscript𝑬stasuperscriptsubscript𝐸1sta…superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑁sta\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}=\{E_{1}^{\text{sta}},...,E_{N}^{\text{sta}}\} can be expressed as

V​(𝑬sta)≈∑n=1NVn​(Ensta)Ensta∈𝑸n.formulae-sequence𝑉superscript𝑬stasuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑉𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛stasuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛stasubscript𝑸𝑛V(\bm{E^{\text{sta}}})\approx\sum_{n=1}^{N}V_{n}(E_{n}^{\text{sta}})\quad E_{n}^{\text{sta}}\in\bm{Q}_{n}. (30)

The global energy state value function V​(𝑬sta)𝑉superscript𝑬staV(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}) is the same as the cardinality of the global energy state 𝑬=[E1,…,EN]𝑬subscript𝐸1…subscript𝐸𝑁\bm{E}=[E_{1},...,E_{N}], and its number is ∏n=1N(Enmax+1)superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max1\prod_{n=1}^{N}(E_{n}^{\text{max}}+1). However, the number of the linear approximation energy state value function of all MDs is ∑n=1N(Enmax+1)superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max1\sum_{n=1}^{N}(E_{n}^{\text{max}}+1). Through linear approximation architecture, we exploit the state value function of each MD Vn​(Ensta)subscript𝑉𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛staV_{n}(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}) with a small state space to represent the global energy state value function V​(𝑬sta)𝑉superscript𝑬staV(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}) with huge state space.

According to Lemma 1 and the linear approximation architecture, we can obtain the following equations,

𝔼𝒉{∑𝑬sta​(t+1)Pr(𝑬sta(t+1)|𝒉(t),𝑬sta(t),𝛀(𝒉(t),𝑬sta(t)))V(𝑬sta(t+1))},=𝔼𝒉{∑𝑬sta​(t+1)(∏n=1NPr(Ensta|𝒉(t),𝑬sta(t),𝛀(𝒉(t),𝑬sta(t)))∑n=1NVn(Ensta(t+1)))},=𝔼𝒉{∑n=1N∑Ensta​(t+1)∈𝑸nPr(Ensta(t+1)|𝒉(t),𝑬sta(t),𝛀(𝒉(t),𝑬sta(t)))Vn(Ensta(t+1))},=𝔼𝒉​{∑n=1N∑An​(t)Pr⁡(An​(t))​Vn​(Ensta​(An​(t),Ωn​(𝑺​(t))))},\begin{split}&\mathbb{E}_{\bm{h}}\bigg{\{}\sum_{\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)}\Pr\left(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)|\bm{h}(t),\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t)\right.,\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\left.\bm{\Omega}(\bm{h}(t),\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t))\right)V(\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1))\bigg{\}},\\ =&\mathbb{E}_{\bm{h}}\bigg{\{}\sum_{\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)}\bigg{(}\prod_{n=1}^{N}\Pr(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}|\bm{h}(t),\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t),\\ &\qquad\qquad\bm{\Omega}(\bm{h}(t),\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t)))\sum_{n=1}^{N}V_{n}(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t+1))\bigg{)}\bigg{\}},\\ =&\mathbb{E}_{\bm{h}}\bigg{\{}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sum_{E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)\in\bm{Q}_{n}}\Pr(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t+1)|\bm{h}(t),\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t),\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\bm{\Omega}(\bm{h}(t),\bm{E}^{\text{sta}}(t)))V_{n}(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t+1))\bigg{\}},\\ =&\mathbb{E}_{\bm{h}}\bigg{\{}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sum_{A_{n}(t)}\Pr(A_{n}(t))V_{n}(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(A_{n}(t),\Omega_{n}(\bm{S}(t))))\bigg{\}},\end{split} (31)

where the post-action energy state of the n𝑛n-th MD Ensta​(An​(t),Ωn​(𝑺​(t)))superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛stasubscript𝐴𝑛𝑡subscriptΩ𝑛𝑺𝑡E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(A_{n}(t),\Omega_{n}(\bm{S}(t))) can be defined as

Ensta​(An​(t),Ωn​(𝑺​(t)))=min⁡{[Ensta​(t)−⌈Encom​(t)+Encop​(t)⌉]++An​(t),Enmax}.superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛stasubscript𝐴𝑛𝑡subscriptΩ𝑛𝑺𝑡superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛sta𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛com𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛cop𝑡subscript𝐴𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max\begin{split}&E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(A_{n}(t),\Omega_{n}(\bm{S}(t)))=\\ &\min\Big{\{}\Big{[}E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t)-\left\lceil E_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)+E_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t)\right\rceil\Big{]}^{+}+A_{n}(t),E_{n}^{\text{max}}\Big{\}}.\end{split} (32)

The equation (31) holds due to the state transition probability in (7) and the state update in (32). Thus, we can get the following optimal policy by (31),

𝛀∗(𝑬(t))=argmax𝛀​(𝑬​(t))𝔼𝒉{g(𝑺(t),𝛀(𝑺(t)),𝜸)+∑n=1N∑An​(t)Pr(An(t))Vn(Ensta(An(t),Ωn(𝑺(t))))}.superscript𝛀𝑬𝑡subscript𝛀𝑬𝑡subscript𝔼𝒉𝑔𝑺𝑡𝛀𝑺𝑡𝜸superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptsubscript𝐴𝑛𝑡Prsubscript𝐴𝑛𝑡subscript𝑉𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛stasubscript𝐴𝑛𝑡subscriptΩ𝑛𝑺𝑡\begin{split}&\bm{\Omega}^{*}(\bm{E}(t))=\arg\max_{\bm{\Omega}(\bm{E}(t))}\mathbb{E}_{\bm{h}}\bigg{\{}g(\bm{S}(t),\bm{\Omega}(\bm{S}(t)),\bm{\gamma})\\ &\qquad+\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sum_{A_{n}(t)}\Pr(A_{n}(t))V_{n}(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(A_{n}(t),\Omega_{n}(\bm{S}(t))))\bigg{\}}.\end{split} (33)

According to the linear value approximation structure (30) and (33), the control policy problem can be re-written as the following problem.

Problem 5:

(Equivalent control policy problem)

max𝛀∗𝔼𝒉{g(𝑺(t),𝛀(𝑺(t)),𝜸)+∑n=1N∑An​(t)Pr(An(t))Vn(Ensta(An(t),Ωn(𝑺(t))))},s.t.0≤Pn​(t)≤Pnmax,ϵn​(t)∈{0,1},(9),(10)​and​(12),∀n.\begin{split}&\max_{\bm{\Omega}^{*}}\mathbb{E}_{\bm{h}}\bigg{\{}g(\bm{S}(t),\bm{\Omega}(\bm{S}(t)),\bm{\gamma})\\ &\qquad+\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sum_{A_{n}(t)}\Pr(A_{n}(t))V_{n}(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(A_{n}(t),\Omega_{n}(\bm{S}(t))))\bigg{\}},\\ &\quad\textrm{s.t.}\qquad 0\leq P_{n}(t)\leq P_{n}^{\text{max}},\\ &\qquad\qquad\epsilon_{n}(t)\in\{0,1\},\\ &\qquad\qquad(\ref{delay constrains}),\ (\ref{energy constrains})\ \text{and}\ (\ref{subchannel allocation constraint}),\forall n.\end{split} (34)

Since Ensta​(An​(t),Ωn​(𝑺​(t)))subscriptsuperscript𝐸sta𝑛subscript𝐴𝑛𝑡subscriptΩ𝑛𝑺𝑡E^{\text{sta}}_{n}(A_{n}(t),\Omega_{n}(\bm{S}(t))) represents the update of the local energy state, we need to calculate the objective function of (34) for each local energy state, and derive the objective function over all local energy states. To solve (34), we expand V​(Ensta​(An​(t),Ωn​(𝑺​(t))))𝑉superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛stasubscript𝐴𝑛𝑡subscriptΩ𝑛𝑺𝑡V(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(A_{n}(t),\Omega_{n}(\bm{S}(t)))) in (34) using Taylor expansion as follows [34, 35]:

V​(Ensta​(An​(t),Ωn​(𝑺​(t))))=V​(Ensta​(t))+(An​(t)−⌈Encom​(t)+Encop​(t)⌉)​V′​(Ensta​(t)),whereV′​(Ensta​(t))=[V​(Ensta​(t)+1)−V​(Ensta​(t)−1)]/2.formulae-sequence𝑉superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛stasubscript𝐴𝑛𝑡subscriptΩ𝑛𝑺𝑡𝑉superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛sta𝑡subscript𝐴𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛com𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛cop𝑡superscript𝑉′superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛sta𝑡wheresuperscript𝑉′subscriptsuperscript𝐸sta𝑛𝑡delimited-[]𝑉superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛sta𝑡1𝑉superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛sta𝑡12\begin{split}&V(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(A_{n}(t),\Omega_{n}(\bm{S}(t))))=V(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t))\\ &\qquad\quad+\left(A_{n}(t)-\left\lceil E_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)+E_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t)\right\rceil\right)V^{\prime}(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t)),\\ &\textrm{where}\\ &V^{\prime}(E^{\text{sta}}_{n}(t))=\left[V(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t)+1)-V(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t)-1)\right]/2.\end{split} (35)

The optimization objective in (34) can be expressed as follow,

max𝛀𝔼𝒉{g(𝑺(t),𝛀(𝑺(t),𝜸)+∑n=1N∑An​(t)Pr(An(t))(V(Ensta(t))+(An(t)−⌈Encom(t)+Encop(t)⌉)V′(Ensta(t)))}.\begin{split}\max_{\bm{\Omega}}\quad&\mathbb{E}_{\bm{h}}\Big{\{}g(\bm{S}(t),\bm{\Omega}(\bm{S}(t),\bm{\gamma})\\ &+\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sum_{A_{n}(t)}\Pr(A_{n}(t))(V(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t))+(A_{n}(t)-\\ &\left.\left\lceil E_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)+E_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t)\right\rceil\right)V^{\prime}(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t)))\Big{\}}.\end{split} (36)

In this way, we can obtain the equivalent optimization problem at the current iteration shown as follow, which is equivalent to (34),

max𝒃,ϵ,𝑷g​(𝑺​(t),𝛀​(𝑺​(t)),𝜸)+∑n=1N∑An​(t)Pr⁡(An​(t))×(An​(t)−⌈Encom​(t)+Encop​(t)⌉)​V′​(Ensta​(t)),s.t.(9),(10)​and​(12),ϵn​(t)∈{0,1}, 0≤Pn​(t)≤Pnmax,∀n,t,\begin{split}&\max_{\bm{b},\bm{\epsilon},\bm{P}}\quad g(\bm{S}(t),\bm{\Omega}(\bm{S}(t)),\bm{\gamma})+\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sum_{A_{n}(t)}\Pr(A_{n}(t))\\ &\qquad\times(A_{n}(t)-\left\lceil E_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)+E_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t)\right\rceil)V^{\prime}(E_{n}^{\text{sta}}(t)),\\ &\textrm{s.t.}\quad\qquad(\ref{delay constrains}),\ (\ref{energy constrains})\ \text{and}\ (\ref{subchannel allocation constraint}),\\ &\qquad\qquad\epsilon_{n}(t)\in\{0,1\},\\ &\qquad\qquad\ 0\leq P_{n}(t)\leq P_{n}^{\text{max}},\quad\forall n,t,\end{split} (37)

where (37) is a static mixed variable optimization problem, in which 𝒃𝒃\bm{b} and 𝑷𝑷\bm{P} are continuous variables, while ϵbold-italic-ϵ\bm{\epsilon} are discrete variables. Besides, the ceiling operator ⌈⋅⌉⋅\left\lceil\cdot\right\rceil is difficult to handle, which brings great difficulties to the optimization problem. In order to solve the problem caused by the ceiling operator ⌈⋅⌉⋅\left\lceil\cdot\right\rceil, we introduce a series of auxiliary variables Δ​En​(t),∀nΔsubscript𝐸𝑛𝑡for-all𝑛\Delta E_{n}(t),\forall n to simplify the optimization problem. The optimization problem can be further described as follow:

max𝒃,ϵ,𝑷g​(𝑺​(t),𝛀​(t),𝜸)+∑n=1N∑An​(t)Pr⁡(An​(t))×(An​(t)−Δ​En​(t))​V′​(En​(t))s.t.(9)​and​(12),Encom​(t)+Encop​(t)−Δ​En​(t)≤0,Δ​En​(t)∈{0,1,2,…,En​(t)},ϵn​(t)∈{0,1}, 0≤Pn​(t)≤Pnmax,∀n,\begin{split}&\max_{\bm{b},\bm{\epsilon},\bm{P}}\quad g(\bm{S}(t),\bm{\Omega}(t),\bm{\gamma})+\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sum_{A_{n}(t)}\Pr(A_{n}(t))\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\times(A_{n}(t)-\Delta E_{n}(t))V^{\prime}(E_{n}(t))\\ &\quad\textrm{s.t.}\qquad(\ref{delay constrains})\ \text{and}\ (\ref{subchannel allocation constraint}),\\ &\qquad\qquad E_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)+E_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t)-\Delta E_{n}(t)\leq 0,\\ &\qquad\qquad\Delta E_{n}(t)\in\{0,1,2,...,E_{n}(t)\},\\ &\qquad\qquad\epsilon_{n}(t)\in\{0,1\},\\ &\qquad\qquad\,0\leq P_{n}(t)\leq P_{n}^{\text{max}},\quad\forall n,\end{split} (38)

where the auxiliary variable is

Δ​En​(t)=⌈Encom​(t)+Encop​(t)⌉=⌈α​bn​(t)​Cn​fn2+ϵn​(t)​Pn​(t)​dRn,s​(t)⌉.Δsubscript𝐸𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛com𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛cop𝑡𝛼subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝐶𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡𝑑subscript𝑅𝑛𝑠𝑡\begin{split}\Delta E_{n}(t)=&\left\lceil E_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)+E_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t)\right\rceil\\ =&\left\lceil\alpha b_{n}(t){C_{n}}{f_{n}^{2}}+\frac{{{\epsilon_{n}(t)P_{n}(t)}d}}{{R_{n,s}(t)}}\right\rceil.\end{split} (39)

Note that the constraints (12) describes the sub-channel constraints of all MDs, we ignore the constraints for the time being to simplify the optimization problem. Given a typical MD n𝑛n, we can obtain the following optimization problem by further analysis and simplification of (37),

maxbn,ϵn,PnΔ​En​(t)−Encom​(t)α​Cn​fn2​ϵn​(t)−Δ​En​(t)​V′​(En​(t)),s.t.Tncom​(t)+Tncop​(t)≤τ,Δ​En​(t)∈{0,1,2,…,En​(t)},ϵn​(t)∈{0,1},0≤Pn​(t)≤Pnmax,∀n.\begin{split}&\max_{b_{n},\epsilon_{n},P_{n}}\quad\frac{\Delta E_{n}(t)-E_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)}{\alpha C_{n}f_{n}^{2}}\epsilon_{n}(t)-\Delta E_{n}(t)V^{\prime}(E_{n}(t)),\\ &\qquad\textrm{s.t.}\qquad T_{n}^{\text{com}}(t)+T_{n}^{\text{cop}}(t)\leq\tau,\\ &\qquad\qquad\quad\Delta E_{n}(t)\in\{0,1,2,...,E_{n}(t)\},\\ &\qquad\qquad\quad\epsilon_{n}(t)\in\{0,1\},\\ &\qquad\qquad\quad 0\leq P_{n}(t)\leq P_{n}^{\text{max}},\quad\forall n.\end{split} (40)

From (40), we can draw the following conclusion obviously: if Δ​En​(t)≤Enth​(t)Δsubscript𝐸𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛th𝑡\Delta E_{n}(t)\leq E_{n}^{\text{th}}(t), then Pn​(t)=0subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡0P_{n}(t)=0 and ϵn​(t)=0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑡0\epsilon_{n}(t)=0, in which Enth​(t)superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛th𝑡E_{n}^{\text{th}}(t) means the threshold energy of the n𝑛n-th MD at the current iteration, and it can be expressed as,

Enth​(t)=τ​σ2hn​(t)​(2dW​τ−1).superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛th𝑡𝜏superscript𝜎2subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡superscript2𝑑𝑊𝜏1E_{n}^{\text{th}}(t)=\frac{\tau\sigma^{2}}{h_{n}(t)}\left(2^{\frac{d}{W\tau}}-1\right). (41)

When Δ​En​(t)≤EnthΔsubscript𝐸𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛th\Delta E_{n}(t)\leq E_{n}^{\text{th}}, the energy consumed by the n𝑛n-th MD at the current iteration is insufficient to support uploading model parameters to the edge server within the iteration duration τ𝜏\tau.

Due to the first constraint of (40), we obtain the upper bound of energy consumption by the n𝑛n-th MD at the iteration t𝑡t, that is,

Δ​En​(t)≤(τ−Tncom​(t))​α​fn3+Tncom​(t)​Pn​(t).Δsubscript𝐸𝑛𝑡𝜏subscriptsuperscript𝑇com𝑛𝑡𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛3subscriptsuperscript𝑇com𝑛𝑡subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡\Delta E_{n}(t)\leq(\tau-T^{\text{com}}_{n}(t))\alpha f_{n}^{3}+T^{\text{com}}_{n}(t)P_{n}(t). (42)

When 1α​Cn​fn2−V′​(En​(t))≤01𝛼subscript𝐶𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛2superscript𝑉′subscript𝐸𝑛𝑡0\frac{1}{\alpha C_{n}f_{n}^{2}}-V^{\prime}(E_{n}(t))\leq 0, the energy consumption Δ​En​(t)Δsubscript𝐸𝑛𝑡\Delta E_{n}(t) is 00 obviously. Correspondingly, the transmission power Pn​(t)subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡P_{n}(t) of the n𝑛n-th MD, the transmission decision ϵn​(t)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑡\epsilon_{n}(t) of the n𝑛n-th MD and the batch size of local training data bn​(t)subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n}(t) are all 00. When 1α​Cn​fn2−V′​(En​(t))>01𝛼subscript𝐶𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛2superscript𝑉′subscript𝐸𝑛𝑡0\frac{1}{\alpha C_{n}f_{n}^{2}}-V^{\prime}(E_{n}(t))>0 and Δ​En​(t)>Enth​(t)Δsubscript𝐸𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛th𝑡\Delta E_{n}(t)>E_{n}^{\text{th}}(t), since the value of Pn​(t)subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡P_{n}(t) is related to the value of Δ​En​(t)Δsubscript𝐸𝑛𝑡\Delta E_{n}(t) and Δ​En​(t)≤(τ−Tncom​(t))​α​fn3+Tncom​(t)​Pn​(t)Δsubscript𝐸𝑛𝑡𝜏subscriptsuperscript𝑇com𝑛𝑡𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛3subscriptsuperscript𝑇com𝑛𝑡subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡\Delta E_{n}(t)\leq(\tau-T^{\text{com}}_{n}(t))\alpha f_{n}^{3}+T^{\text{com}}_{n}(t)P_{n}(t), the energy consumption Δ​En​(t)Δsubscript𝐸𝑛𝑡\Delta E_{n}(t) of the n𝑛n-th MD take the maximum value, i.e.,

Δ​En​(t)=(τ−dRn,s​(t))​α​fn3+dRn,s​(t)​Pn​(t).Δsubscript𝐸𝑛𝑡𝜏𝑑subscript𝑅𝑛𝑠𝑡𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛3𝑑subscript𝑅𝑛𝑠𝑡subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡\Delta E_{n}(t)=\left(\tau-\frac{d}{R_{n,s}(t)}\right)\alpha f_{n}^{3}+\frac{d}{R_{n,s}(t)}P_{n}(t). (43)

Since Pn​(t)∈(0,Pnmax]subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡0subscriptsuperscript𝑃max𝑛P_{n}(t)\in(0,P^{\text{max}}_{n}] and Δ​En​(t)Δsubscript𝐸𝑛𝑡\Delta E_{n}(t) increases monotonically as Pn​(t)subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡P_{n}(t) increases, there is a maximum value of Δ​Enmax​(t)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max𝑡\Delta E_{n}^{\text{max}}(t) as a function of Pn​(t)subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡P_{n}(t), which can be expressed as,

Δ​Enmax​(t)=(τ−dRn,smax​(t))​α​fn3+dRn,smax​(t)​Pnmax.Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max𝑡𝜏𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑛𝑠max𝑡𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛3𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑛𝑠max𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛max\Delta E_{n}^{\text{max}}(t)=\left(\tau-\frac{d}{R_{n,s}^{\text{max}}(t)}\right)\alpha f_{n}^{3}+\frac{d}{R_{n,s}^{\text{max}}(t)}P_{n}^{\text{max}}. (44)

Thus, when Δ​En​(t)>Δ​Enmax​(t)Δsubscript𝐸𝑛𝑡Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max𝑡\Delta E_{n}(t)>\Delta E_{n}^{\text{max}}(t), the transmit power Pn​(t)subscript𝑃𝑛𝑡P_{n}(t) is Pnmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛maxP_{n}^{\text{max}}, ϵn​(t)=1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑡1\epsilon_{n}(t)=1 and the batch size bn​(t)subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n}(t) for local training can be expresses as following,

bn​(t)=Δ​Enmax​(t)−En,maxcom​(t)α​Cn​fn2,subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡Δsubscriptsuperscript𝐸max𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛maxcom𝑡𝛼subscript𝐶𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛2\begin{split}b_{n}(t)=\frac{\Delta E^{\text{max}}_{n}(t)-E_{n,\text{max}}^{\text{com}}(t)}{\alpha C_{n}f_{n}^{2}},\end{split} (45)

IV-C Convergence Analysis

We need to provide effective analysis for the convergence of the online stochastic learning algorithm, which is shown in Algorithm 2. From the previous section, we notice that there are two different step size sequences {ϵvt}superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑡\{\epsilon_{v}^{t}\} and {ϵγt}superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝛾𝑡\{\epsilon_{\gamma}^{t}\} in the stochastic learning process, which are used for the update of state value functions of MDs and Lagrange Multipliers respectively. Since the update of the Lagrangian multiplier 𝜸𝜸\bm{\gamma} and the update of the value function 𝑽𝑽\bm{V} occur simultaneously and ϵγt=𝒐​(ϵvt)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝛾𝑡𝒐superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑡\epsilon_{\gamma}^{t}=\bm{o}(\epsilon_{v}^{t}), we can obtain γt+1−γt=𝒐​(ϵvt)superscript𝛾𝑡1superscript𝛾𝑡𝒐superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑡\gamma^{t+1}-\gamma^{t}=\bm{o}(\epsilon_{v}^{t}). Therefore, we consider that the Lagrangian multipliers does not change when the state value function is updated. Therefore, we assume that the Lagrangian multipliers 𝜸tsuperscript𝜸𝑡\bm{\gamma}^{t} keep static when the value functions of the mobile devices are updated in (49).

The relationship between the the global value function vector 𝑽𝑽\bm{V} and the parameter vector 𝑾𝑾\bm{W} can be expressed as,

𝑽=𝑴​𝑾and𝑾=𝑴†​𝑽,formulae-sequence𝑽𝑴𝑾and𝑾superscript𝑴†𝑽\bm{V}=\bm{MW}\qquad\text{and}\qquad\bm{W}=\bm{M}^{\dagger}\bm{V}, (53)

in which 𝑴∈ℝ|IS|×∑n=1N(Enmax+1)𝑴superscriptℝsubscript𝐼𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max1\bm{M}\in\mathbb{R}^{|I_{S}|\times\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left(E_{n}^{\text{max}}+1\right)} with the k𝑘kth row (k=1,2,…,|IS|𝑘12…subscript𝐼𝑆k=1,2,...,|I_{S}|) equal to 𝑭​(𝑬k)𝑭superscript𝑬𝑘\bm{F}(\bm{E}^{k}), where 𝑬ksuperscript𝑬𝑘\bm{E}^{k} is the k𝑘kth global energy state and |IS|subscript𝐼𝑆|I_{S}| is the cardinality of the system state. In addition, 𝑴†∈ℝ∑n=1N(Enmax+1)×|IS|superscript𝑴†superscriptℝsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max1subscript𝐼𝑆\bm{M}^{\dagger}\in\mathbb{R}^{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left(E_{n}^{\text{max}}+1\right)\times|I_{S}|} means the mapping matrix from 𝑽𝑽\bm{V} to 𝑾𝑾\bm{W}, which is the inverse mapping of the first equation of (53). We then have the following convergence lemma on the local state value function for each MD in the stochastic learning.

Lemma 2:

(Convergence of State Value Function of each MD): The convergence performance of the state value function can be expressed mathematically as follows.

  1. 1.

    The update of the state value function vector converge almost surely for any given initial parameter vector 𝑾0superscript𝑾0\bm{W}^{0} and Lagrange multiplier γ𝛾\gamma, which can be expressed as

    limt→∞𝑾t​(γ)=𝑾∞​(γ).subscript→𝑡superscript𝑾𝑡𝛾superscript𝑾𝛾\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\bm{W}^{t}(\gamma)=\bm{W}^{\infty}(\gamma). (54)
  2. 2.

    The local steady-state value function vector 𝑾∞superscript𝑾\bm{W}^{\infty} satisfies the vector form of the following steady equivalent Bellman equation,

    θ​𝑰+𝑾∞​(γ)=𝑴†​𝑻​(γ,𝑴​𝑾∞​(γ)),𝜃𝑰superscript𝑾𝛾superscript𝑴†𝑻𝛾𝑴superscript𝑾𝛾\theta\bm{I}+\bm{W}^{\infty}(\gamma)=\bm{M}^{\dagger}\bm{T}\left(\gamma,\bm{M}\bm{W}^{\infty}(\gamma)\right), (55)

    where 𝑰𝑰\bm{I} is a ∑n=1N(Enmax+1)×1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max11\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left(E_{n}^{\text{max}}+1\right)\times 1 vector whose elements are all equal to 111, 𝑻𝑻\bm{T} represents a function mapping, which can be defined as,

    𝑻​(γ,𝑽)=maxΩ⁡{𝒈¯​(γ,Ω)+𝑷​(Ω)​𝑽}𝑻𝛾𝑽subscriptΩ¯𝒈𝛾Ω𝑷Ω𝑽\bm{T}(\gamma,\bm{V})=\max_{\Omega}\left\{\overline{\bm{g}}\left(\gamma,\Omega\right)+\bm{P}(\Omega)\bm{V}\right\} (56)

    where 𝒈¯​(γ,Ω)¯𝒈𝛾Ω\overline{\bm{g}}\left(\gamma,\Omega\right) is a ∑n=1N(Enmax+1)×1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛max11\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left(E_{n}^{\text{max}}+1\right)\times 1 vector of function g¯​(𝑬,Ω​(𝑬))¯𝑔𝑬Ω𝑬\overline{g}\left(\bm{E},\Omega(\bm{E})\right), which is defined in (22). 𝑷​(Ω)𝑷Ω\bm{P}(\Omega) is the matrix form of transition probability Pr​(𝑬t+1|𝑬t,Ω)Prconditionalsuperscript𝑬𝑡1superscript𝑬𝑡Ω\text{Pr}(\bm{E}^{t+1}|\bm{E}^{t},\Omega) defined in (22).

Proof: Following [35], we briefly explain the Lemma. Since we consider the stochastic channels, where the channel gain varies within the interval, it is easy to see that each state will be updated comparably often in the asynchronous learning algorithm. Quoting the conclusion in [35], the convergence property of the asynchronous update and synchronous update is the same. Therefore, we just consider the convergence of related synchronous version for simplicity in this proof. According to the definition of parameter vector 𝐖𝐖\bm{W} and the bounded per-MD value function Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n}, it is clearly that the update on the per-MD value function vector is equivalent to the update on the parameter vector and to prove the convergence of the Lemma is equivalent to prove the convergence of update on the parameter vector 𝐖𝐖\bm{W}. The proof of details can refer to [35].

Due to ϵγt=𝒐​(ϵvt)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝛾𝑡𝒐superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑡\epsilon_{\gamma}^{t}=\bm{o}(\epsilon_{v}^{t}), the ratio of step sizes between state value function and Lagrange Multiplier can be expressed as ϵγtϵvt→0→superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝛾𝑡superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑡0\frac{\epsilon_{\gamma}^{t}}{\epsilon_{v}^{t}}\rightarrow 0 during the Lagrange Multiplier update in (51), and the updates of the local state value function are much faster than the Lagrange Multiplier. Thus, the Lagrange Multiplier can be consider as quasi-invariant during the update of the local state value functions of each MD, and the update of the Lagrange Multiplier will trigger another update process of the local state value function of each MD. According to [36], we can obtain that limt→∞‖Vnt−Vn∞​(γt)‖=0subscript→𝑡normsubscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑡𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑛superscript𝛾𝑡0\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}||V^{t}_{n}-V^{\infty}_{n}(\gamma^{t})||=0, in which Vn∞​(γt)subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑛superscript𝛾𝑡V^{\infty}_{n}(\gamma^{t}) means the converged local state value function of n𝑛nth MD with Lagrange Multiplier γtsuperscript𝛾𝑡\gamma^{t}. Therefore, the update of the local state value function can be considered as almost constant during the Lagrange Multiplier s update. Then, we need to the convergence lemma of the Lagrange Multipliers.

Lemma 3:

(Convergence of the Lagrange Multipliers): The iteration on the Lagrange Multipliers 𝛄𝛄\bm{\gamma} converges almost surely to the set of minimum of G​(𝛄)𝐺𝛄G(\bm{\gamma}) in (18). Supposing that the Lagrange Multipliers converge to 𝛄∗superscript𝛄\bm{\gamma}^{*}, then 𝛄∗superscript𝛄\bm{\gamma}^{*} satisfies the average energy outage constraint in (11).

Proof: Quoting to [37, Lemma 4.2], −G​(𝛄)𝐺𝛄-G(\bm{\gamma}) is a concave and continuously differentiable except at finitely many points where both right and left derivatives exist. Thus, G​(𝛄)𝐺𝛄G(\bm{\gamma}) is a convex function of γ𝛾\gamma. Since the energy consumption policy of each MD is discrete, we can obtain that Ω∗​(γ)=Ω∗​(γ+Δγ)superscriptΩ𝛾superscriptΩ𝛾subscriptΔ𝛾\Omega^{*}(\gamma)=\Omega^{*}(\gamma+\Delta_{\gamma}), i.e., ∇γ=(Ω∗​(γ+Δγ)−Ω∗​(γ))/Δγ=0subscript∇𝛾superscriptΩ𝛾subscriptΔ𝛾superscriptΩ𝛾subscriptΔ𝛾0\nabla_{\gamma}=(\Omega^{*}(\gamma+\Delta_{\gamma})-\Omega^{*}(\gamma))/\Delta_{\gamma}=0. Thus, ∂G​(γt)/∂γt𝐺superscript𝛾𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡\partial G(\gamma^{t})/\partial\gamma^{t} can be expressed as ∂G​(γt)/∂γt=𝔼Ω∗​(γt)​{PrnE−𝟏​[En​(t)=0]}𝐺superscript𝛾𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡superscript𝔼superscriptΩsuperscript𝛾𝑡superscriptsubscriptPr𝑛𝐸1delimited-[]subscript𝐸𝑛𝑡0\partial G(\gamma^{t})/\partial\gamma^{t}=\mathbb{E}^{\Omega^{*}(\gamma^{t})}\{\text{Pr}_{n}^{E}-\bm{1}[E_{n}(t)=0]\}, where Ω∗​(γt)=arg⁡maxΩ⁡G​(γt)superscriptΩsuperscript𝛾𝑡subscriptΩ𝐺superscript𝛾𝑡\Omega^{*}(\gamma^{t})=\arg\max_{\Omega}G(\gamma^{t}). By the standard stochastic approximation theorem [38], the dynamics of the Lagrange Multiplier update can be represented by ordinary differential equation (ODE). According to [39], we know that that the ODE equals to ∂G​(γt)/∂γt𝐺superscript𝛾𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡\partial G(\gamma^{t})/\partial\gamma^{t}. Thus, the aforementioned ODE will converge to ∂G​(γt)/∂γt=0𝐺superscript𝛾𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡0\partial G(\gamma^{t})/\partial\gamma^{t}=0, i.e., the the average energy outage constraints are satisfied. ■■\hfill\blacksquare

According to Lemma 2 and 3, the iteration on local state value function and the Lagrange Multipliers in Algorithm 2 will converge.

V Simulation And Discussion

In this section, we evaluate the performance of the proposed algorithm using numerical results. In the simulations, all MDs are randomly distributed in a fixed region. We set the bandwidth of channel between each MD and the edge server as 0.1​MHz0.1MHz0.1\text{MHz}. The number of CPU cycles C𝐶C for each MD to perform local model training of unit data sampling takes range from 1010​cycle/unitsuperscript1010cycle/unit10^{10}\text{cycle/unit} to 1.9∗1010​cycle/unit1.9superscript1010cycle/unit1.9*10^{10}\text{cycle/unit}. The simulation parameters are detailed in Table II.

We compare our proposed approximate MDP solution with online stochastic learning with three other reference control algorithms. One is the CSI-based MDP algorithm, where the edge server takes corresponding decisions based on the channel state only at the current iteration so as to optimize average utility of all MDs. The second reference control algorithm is myopic method, which is a method that only considers the current utility. In myopic method, the edge server never considers long-term utilities. The last reference control algorithm is a random resource scheduling method, where the edge server takes random actions in the feasible regions. The performance of the proposed algorithm is evaluated by averaging over 5000 experiments.

Fig. 2 illustrates the long-term average utility 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} v.s. the mean arrival rate λ𝜆\lambda of the random new arrived energy with Emax=6​Jsuperscript𝐸max6JE^{\text{max}}=6\text{J}. It can be observed that the performance of the online stochastic learning algorithm is better than the other reference algorithms for all the investigated average arrival rate λ𝜆\lambda. When the value of the mean arrival rate λ𝜆\lambda is relatively small, the performance of online learning is close to that of other reference algorithms, especially the CSI-based MDP algorithm. The cause of this phenomenon is twofold. First, the small mean arrival rate λ𝜆\lambda of energy will result in a limited energy level in the battery of the MD. Due to insufficient battery energy, MDs are constrained with a small space of actions compared with those with sufficient battery power. The second reason is that a large amount of battery energy is used for uploading local parameters. When the battery energy of MD is insufficient, the energy for local training of FL is smaller, which leads to smaller long-term average utility. In contrast, when the battery level is high, MD's actions will become more diverse, and more energy will be used for local training in FL process.

Fig. 3 illustrates the long-term average utility 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} v.s. the maximum battery capacity Emaxsuperscript𝐸maxE^{\text{max}} of MD. We observe that the long-term average utility increases as the maximum battery capacity Emaxsuperscript𝐸maxE^{\text{max}} of MD increases in all algorithms,although the mean arrival rate λ𝜆\lambda of the arrival energy has never changed. It indicates that the long-term average utility 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} increases approximately linearly with the maximum battery capacity Emaxsuperscript𝐸maxE^{\text{max}} in our proposed algorithm.

Fig. 4 shows the impact of the number of CPU cycles for MD to perform local model training of unit data sampling C𝐶C on the long-term average utility 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}. It is obvious that the long-term average utility decreases as the number of CPU cycles for unit training data sampling C𝐶C. In addition, as the number of CPU cycles for unit training data sampling C𝐶C continues to increase, performance differences among different algorithms also decrease. Fig. 5 depicts the long-term average utility 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} v.s. the computation capacity f𝑓f of MD. Intuitively, the MDs with more computing capacity will lead to a higher long-term average utility 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}. However, the opposite is true, it is caused by (3) and the limited energy of MD in each iteration. In other words, a more powerful computing capacity requires more computing energy. Due to the limited amounts of energy available to MDs in each iteration, MDs can only reduce the size of sampling data used for local training.

Fig. 6 describes the relationship among the wireless channel state, the energy state of MD and the transmission power policy. In our simulation settings, H1subscript𝐻1H_{1} represents the worst channel state, while H5subscript𝐻5H_{5} represents the best channel state in our system. From the figure, we can see that the MD avoids data transmission to save battery energy when the MD is in a very poor channel state (H1subscript𝐻1H_{1}). In addition, we find that for a given channel state the transmission power monotonously increases with the energy state of the MD.

Fig. 7 illustrates the convergence property of the proposed distributed online learning algorithm. It can be seen that the online stochastic algorithm converges quite fast and after 1500 iterations, the values are close to the final converged results. Moreover, it is clear that the value functions calculated online quickly approach the the final converged results when the number of iterations grows.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we study a constrained MDP problem of FL with a MEC sever, where each MDs send local model updates trained on their local sensitive data iteratively to the edge server, and the edge server aggregates the parameters from MDs and broadcasts the aggregated parameters to MDs. We first model the resource scheduling problem in the synchronous FL process as a constrained MDP problem, and we use the size of the training samples as the performance of FL for analysis. Due to the coupling between iterations and the complexity of the state-action space, we cannot directly solve the constrained MDP problem. Thus, we analyze the problem by equivalent Bellman equations and use approximate MDP and stochastic learning methods to simplify the constrained MDP problem so as to approximate the state value function. Then we design static algorithm to obtain the static policy for each MD based the approximate state value function. Finally, we provide theoretical analysis for the convergence of the online stochastic learning algorithm. The simulation results show that the performance of the stochastic leaning is better than various benchmark schemes.
